isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - DETROIT DIESEL SERIES 60 - 1992-1993 - TROUBLESHOOTING - THROTTLE POSITION SENSOR

svcprocinfo.para: Inspect throttle position sensor circuits and connectors as outlined in paragraph 6.0.1.

svcsubproc.title: Testing Throttle Position Sensor Circuits
svcsubproc.para: It is important to test the Throttle Position Sensor circuits for short circuits (HIGH and LOW) and for circuit continuity before performing Testing Throttle Position Sensor.

svcsubproc.title: Testing Throttle Position Sensor (TPS)
svcsubproc.para: Test 6.1.2 requires the use of the Prolink EST to identify proper operation of the pedal. The Prolink EST identifies the number of counts which are being sent to the ECM for interpretation of throttle position. Refer to Prolink manual for this operation.

The full range of counts is from 0 to 256, which can be translated to: one count = 19.5 mV input signal. The voltage range of the pedal is 0 volts to 5.0 volts. Normal operation with the Series 60 engine is a range of 20-30 counts at idle, 31-214 counts for normal operation and 215-235 counts for wide-open throttle.
The counts from 0-19 will cause an out-of-range LOW (ORL) fault code. Counts from 235-256 will cause an out-of-range HIGH (ORH) fault code.
It is important to note that TPS circuit defects can cause the same codes as a defective pedal, so the circuits must be checked prior to checking the pedal.
